notes:
# HTML - Introduction - W3Schools.com

HTML stands for Hyper Text Markup Language. It's the foundation of the World Wide Web, defining the structure and content of web pages. HTML is a markup language, meaning it uses tags to define elements and their content. You'll learn about the basic structure of an HTML document, including the `<!DOCTYPE html>` declaration, the `<html>` tag, the `<head>` and `<body>` sections, and basic elements like headings, paragraphs, and links.

# HTML - Editors - W3Schools.com

To create and edit HTML files, you'll need a text editor. There are many options available, ranging from simple text editors like Notepad (Windows) or TextEdit (Mac) to more advanced code editors like Visual Studio Code, Atom, or Sublime Text. These editors provide features like syntax highlighting, auto-completion, and code formatting, making HTML development easier.

# HTML - Elements - W3Schools.com HTML elements are the building blocks of web pages. Each element is represented by a tag, such as `

` for paragraphs, `

` for headings, and `` for images. Elements can contain attributes that provide additional information. You'll explore common HTML elements, learn how to nest them properly, and understand their purpose.

# HTML - Attributes - W3Schools.com Attributes provide additional information about HTML elements. They are written within the opening tag and come in key-value pairs. For example, the `` element has the `src` attribute to specify the image source, and the `` (anchor) element has the `href` attribute to define the link's destination. You'll learn about essential attributes for various elements.

# HTML - Headings - W3Schools.com

Headings are used to structure content and provide hierarchical organization. HTML offers six heading levels (`<h1>` to `<h6>`), with `<h1>` being the most important and `<h6>` the least. Headings are displayed larger and bolder than regular text. You'll understand how to use headings effectively to improve readability and SEO.

# HTML - Paragraphs - W3Schools.com Paragraphs are the main way to present text in HTML. The `

` tag is used to create paragraphs. Multiple paragraphs can be created by using separate `

` tags. You'll learn about paragraph formatting, line breaks, and how to create different paragraph styles using CSS.

# HTML - Styles - W3Schools.com

Styles determine the appearance of HTML elements. CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) is the language used to style HTML content. You'll get an introduction to CSS, learn how to link external stylesheets, and understand basic CSS properties like font size, color, and background.

# HTML - Formatting - W3Schools.com

HTML provides tags for text formatting, such as `<b>` for bold text, `<i>` for italic text, and `<u>` for underlined text. You'll learn how to use these tags to emphasize specific parts of your text and create different visual effects.

# HTML - Comments - W3Schools.com

Comments are used to add notes or explanations within your HTML code. They are ignored by the browser and are helpful for documentation and debugging. You'll learn how to write single-line and multi-line comments using the `<!--` and `-->` markers.

# HTML - Colors - W3Schools.com

Colors are essential for visual appeal and conveying information in web design. You'll learn about color representation methods like hexadecimal codes, RGB values, and color names. You'll also see how to apply colors to text, backgrounds, and other elements using CSS.

# HTML - CSS - W3Schools.com

CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) is a fundamental part of web development. It separates the styling of your website from the HTML structure. You'll learn about the basic structure of CSS, different ways to apply styles, and core CSS properties for layout, typography, and visual effects.

# HTML - Links - W3Schools.com

Links are crucial for navigation and connecting different parts of the web. The `<a>` (anchor) tag is used to create links. You'll learn how to create links to other web pages, internal sections within the same page, email addresses, and download files.

# HTML - Images - W3Schools.com Images add visual appeal and convey information in web pages. The `` tag is used to embed images. You'll learn about image attributes like `src` (image source), `alt` (alternative text for accessibility), and `width` and `height` for image sizing.

# HTML - Tables - W3Schools.com

Tables are used to organize data in rows and columns. The `<table>` tag creates a table, with `<tr>` for rows, `<th>` for table headers, and `<td>` for table data cells. You'll learn how to create basic tables, format cells, and span rows and columns.

# HTML - Lists - W3Schools.com

Lists are used to present items in an ordered or unordered manner. The `<ul>` tag creates an unordered list, while `<ol>` creates an ordered list. You'll learn how to create different list styles and embed lists within other lists.

# HTML - Block and Inline - W3Schools.com HTML elements can be classified as block-level or inline. Block-level elements like `

` and `

` take up the full width of their container, while inline elements like `` and `` only occupy the space required for their content. You'll understand how block and inline elements affect layout.

# HTML - Classes - W3Schools.com

Classes are used to group elements and apply styles to them selectively. You can use the `class` attribute to assign a class name to an element and then target that class using CSS selectors. This allows for more organized and reusable styling.

# HTML - Id - W3Schools.com

IDs are unique identifiers assigned to HTML elements. They are used to target a specific element using CSS selectors. Unlike classes, IDs must be unique within a document. You'll learn when to use classes and when to use IDs.

# HTML - Iframes - W3Schools.com

Iframes (Inline Frames) are used to embed content from another web page within the current page. The `<iframe>` tag is used to create an iframe. You'll learn how to embed content from external sources like YouTube videos or interactive maps.

# HTML - JavaScript - W3Schools.com

JavaScript is a programming language that adds interactivity and dynamic behavior to web pages. You'll get a brief introduction to JavaScript, its uses, and how it interacts with HTML.

# HTML - Head - W3Schools.com

The `<head>` section of an HTML document contains meta-information about the page, such as the document's title, character set encoding, links to external stylesheets, and scripts. You'll learn about common elements within the `<head>` section.

# HTML - Forms - W3Schools.com

Forms are used to collect user input on websites. You'll learn about the `<form>` tag, form elements like input fields, text areas, dropdown menus, and buttons, and how to process form data.

# HTML - Bloopers - W3Schools.com

This section will cover common mistakes and pitfalls in HTML development, helping you avoid potential errors and write cleaner, more efficient code.
